prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B3 z=1.634 central cluster galaxy 3483
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: A single pointing on this galaxy to get the CO(2-1) line profile, or at least the total line flux

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Sensitivity is set by the peak line flux density, needing 4 sigma detections in 50 km/s bins (the total line flux will thus be easily detected). We need 50 km/s bins to sufficiently sample the 400 km/s wide line in order to deduce a linewidth. We do not aim to detect continuum in band 3 (and 4): we use band 6 and 7 for that.

One baseband contains a spw in FDM mode for measuring the CO(2-1) line at 13 km/s resolution (spectral averaging factor 8), jut in case the line is bright enough to allow smaller bins than the requested 50 km/s. We use the maximum total bandwidth to best sample the continuum (aiding calibration), including the three remaining basebands in TDM mode, although we note that this is still likely to be a 2 sigma detection for our weakest source.

The angular resolution is set to match the typical size of a galaxy in our optical and infrared datasets: about an arcsec. The largest angular scale refers to the possible size of the BCG: about 6 arcsec.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B4 z=1.634 central cluster galaxy 3483
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Two pointings on this galaxy to get the CO(3-2) line profile, or at least the total line flux

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Sensitivity is set by the peak flux density, needing 4 sigma detections in 50 km/s bins (the total line flux will thus be easily detected). We need 50 km/s bins to sufficiently sample the 400 km/s wide line in order to deduce a linewidth. We do not aim to detect continuum in band 4 (and 3): we use band 6 and 7 for that.

One baseband contains a spw in FDM mode for measuring the CO(3-2) line at 9 km/s resolution (spectral averaging factor 8), jut in case the line is bright enough to allow smaller bins than the requested 50 km/s. We use the maximum total bandwidth to best sample the continuum, including the three remaining basebands in TDM mode, although we note that this is still likely to be a 2 sigma detection for our weakest source.

The angular resolution is set to match the typical size of a galaxy in our optical and infrared datasets: about an arcsec. The largest angular scale refers to the possible size of the BCG: 6 arcsec. The two pointings cover the full 18 arcsec SPIRE beam.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B6 z=1.634 central cluster galaxy 3483
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: A five pointings mosaic on this galaxy to get the CO(6-5) line profile

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Sensitivity is set by the peak flux density, requesting 5 sigma detections in 50 km/s bins (the total line flux will thus be easily detected) as the estimates are bit more uncertain than for bands 3 and 4. We need 50 km/s bins to sufficiently sample the 400 km/s wide line in order to deduce a linewidth. With this sensitivity we should detect continuum flux (almost) at the 4 sigma level.

One baseband contains a spw in FDM mode for measuring the CO(5-4) line at 11 km/s resolution (spectral averaging factor 16), jut in case the line is bright enough to allow smaller bins than the requested 50 km/s. We use the maximum total bandwidth to best sample the continuum, including the three remaining basebands in TDM mode. We note that we should get a 3.8 sigma detection in continuum for our weakest source.

The angular resolution is set to match the typical size of a galaxy in our optical and infrared datasets: about an arcsec. The largest angular scale refers to the possible size of the BCG: 6 arcsec. We aim to map the region covered by the SPIRE 18 arcsec beam: we require five pointings to achieve that.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: B7 z=1.634 central cluster galaxy 3483 + 3508
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
A 7 pointing mosaic to fill the beam of one band 3 pointing on top of the SPIRE 250 source, plus four additional pointings to cover the BCG.
The CO(7-6) line at 306.25 GHz is included, just in case.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The aim here is to detect the dust continuum flux at the 5 sigma level, at the same (matching) angular resolution as the other bands. The minimum expected peak continuum flux density is 0.5 mJy, so we require an rms (for the full aggregate bandwidth) of 0.1 mJy, for each of the pointings.

As we aim to detect continuum in this band, we selected the single continuum set-up to get the best sensitivity. The spectral resolution is still good enough to possibly detect the CO(7-6) line in one of the spectral windows.

We use non-standard continuum frequencies to include the CO(7-6) line, which might be detectable. The atmospheric transmission at these frequencies is also slightly better, resulting in slightly shorter integration times.

The angular resolution is set to match the typical size of a galaxy in our optical and infrared datasets: about an arcsec. The largest angular scale refers to the possible size of the BCG: 6 arcsec. We aim to map the region covered by the SPIRE 18 arcsec beam and the BCG: for this we require eleven pointings in total.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: At high redshifts (z>1.4), galaxy clusters and their constituent massive galaxies become structures in an active mass-growth phase. A good example is a z=1.63 galaxy clusters from the SpARCS survey for which we have 25 spectroscopically confirmed cluster members. One of its galaxies, in the core of it, appears to be associated with a bright 250 micron source (most likely a blend of several fainter sources) detected by Herschel/SPIRE. We aim to resolve the confused SPIRE source in ALMA band 7 using seven pointings on and around the galaxy associated with it, and four adjoining pointings on the area towards and including the BCG. This will establish the origin of the 250 micron flux. In addition, we aim to measure the CO(2-1), CO(3-2) and CO(5-4) line fluxes (and possibly linewidths) to estimate the molecular gas mass and temperature of the SPIRE source(s), using ALMA band 3, 4 and 6 respectively. These observations will allow us to study in detail the stellar mass growth of galaxies in the densest high-z environments, a key point towards a complete understanding of massive galaxy formation and evolution.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:relatedProposals:
The SpARCS collaboration is submitting another proposal (PI Allison Noble, 'The first glimpse of CO 2-1 in z=1.6 cluster galaxies' with project code 2015.1.01151.S) that is targeting SpARCS J0224 as well, but in band 3 only. If both proposals are accepted we will retract the band 3 part of our proposal. We note that these proposals are not dependent on each other and have very different science goals.
We are also submitting 2015.1.00004.S (PI: Eelco van Kampen) which aims to detect CO(3-2) in band 4 and continuum band 7 in galaxy pairs within SpARCS J0330; the science goals, target and ALMA bands are therefore very different.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2013.1.00463.S, 'Mass growth at high-z: molecular gas and dust in the core of a galaxy cluster at z=1.63', PI: Demarco (filler project for Cycle 2: any SBs observed after the Cycle 3 deadline will be retracted from this proposal)
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
